portfolio_items.name: Ghosts of Knowledge
portfolio_items.description:
A top-down exploration RPG developed for a 3 week Game Jam competition. This was developed within a French Monster Collecting engine known as PSDK, which utilized Ruby, a little bit of C++, and a graphic engine they developed themselves called LiteRGSS.          
                                                                                                                     
The competition this project was developed for always has a theme and contestants were asked to develop a Pokémon RPG with whatever engine of choice. I decided I'd go for something that would be easier to split in a few weeks, rather than a dedicated gym challenge seen in regular Pokémon games, so this has a fully original story. 

You play as Dust, an explorer who stumbles upon an underwater cave and the world hidden beneath the surface. Unlock paths, gather history, and snag some treasure whenever you can find it!

Working in a team as 4 as the lead developer, I was responsible for:

- Coming up with the story/gameplay loop. This includes writing all of the dialogue. I split the game into three areas, with 5 hidden "treasures" within each. You found these just walking around and exploring the overworld. Collecting them at intervals gave the players various rewards that would help them in battle. They also publicly display at the player's base with fun flavor text. There are also a lot of optional treasures that can still be traded in, but would give a strong random award. Wild Pokémon drop these at a small chance (10%).

- Figuring out how many mechanics we could feasibly import into this game. Turns out, Pokémon has a lot of mechanics, and a lot of conditional ones too. The first thing I did was add just a few moves, and curate fights to make sure the moves that did exist flowed into the gameplay well. Lots of playtesting was in order to check the overall game balance, prioritizing fast fights with very few gauntlets in order to get the player back to the overworld as much as possible, since the focus is on exploring.

- The general game setting and art direction. A ton of the art in this project was either edited and credited public resources or completely sprited from scratch. The biggest outlier was the Pokémon sprites themselves.

- Bringing everyone's contributions together and having the game in a playable and releasable state. The puzzles, map design, and art I had assistance in, but it was on me to make sure that they all make it in the game and works well. 

This marks my first planned game project that was actually able to make the finish line.
